name: Coldplay
description:
'''Coldplay''' are a British [[Rock music|rock]] band formed in [[London]] in 1997. They consist of vocalist and pianist [[Chris Martin]], guitarist [[Jonny Buckland]], bassist [[Guy Berryman]] and drummer [[Will Champion]]; manager [[Phil Harvey (band manager)|Phil Harvey]] is also credited as a full member. The group are known for [[List of Coldplay live performances|their live performances]] and have had a significant [[Cultural impact of Coldplay|impact on popular culture]].

The band initially went by the names Big Fat Noises and Starfish. Following the independent release of the EP ''[[Safety (EP)|Safety]]'' (1998), they signed a record deal with [[Parlophone]] in 1999 and issued their debut album, ''[[Parachutes (Coldplay album)|Parachutes]]'' (2000), which included the breakthrough single "[[Yellow (Coldplay song)|Yellow]]"; the album won a [[Brit Award for British Album of the Year]] and a [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album]]. The follow-up, ''[[A Rush of Blood to the Head]]'' (2002), earned the same accolades. ''[[X&Y]]'' (2005) concluded what Coldplay viewed as a trilogy, and its successor, ''[[Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends]]'' (2008), secured a [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Album]]; both releases topped the charts in over 30 countries, becoming the [[List of best-selling albums#Best-selling album by year worldwide|best-sellers of their respective years]] worldwide. ''Viva la Vida''{{'s}} [[Viva la Vida|title track]] was the first song by a British act to reach number one in the United States and United Kingdom simultaneously in the 21st century.

The albums ''[[Mylo Xyloto]]'' (2011), ''[[Ghost Stories (Coldplay album)|Ghost Stories]]'' (2014), ''[[A Head Full of Dreams]]'' (2015), ''[[Everyday Life (Coldplay album)|Everyday Life]]'' (2019), ''[[Music of the Spheres (Coldplay album)|Music of the Spheres]]'' (2021) and ''[[Moon Music]]'' (2024) drew from genres such as [[electronica]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Ambient music|ambient]], [[disco]], [[funk]], [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[blues]] and [[progressive rock]]. A documentary directed by [[Mat Whitecross]], ''[[Coldplay: A Head Full of Dreams]],'' was released in 2018, Coldplay's 20th anniversary. Their 2021 single "[[My Universe (song)|My Universe]]" was the first song by a British group to debut at number one on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and their [[Music of the Spheres World Tour]] is the [[List of most-attended concert tours|most-attended]] and [[List of highest-grossing concert tours|second-highest-grossing concert tour of all time]]. Coldplay are involved in philanthropy, politics and activism, supporting numerous humanitarian projects and donating 10% of their profits to charity.

With over 160 million records sold worldwide, Coldplay are one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music acts of all time]]. They are also the first group in [[Spotify]] history to reach 90 million [[List of most-streamed artists on Spotify|monthly listeners]]. [[Fuse (TV channel)|Fuse]] listed them among the [[List of awards and nominations received by Coldplay|most awarded artists]], including holding the record for most [[Brit Awards]] won by a band. In the United Kingdom, they have three of the 50 [[List of best-selling albums in the United Kingdom|best-selling albums]], the most [[UK Albums Chart]] number ones without missing the top (10), and are the most played group of the 21st century on British media. The [[British Phonographic Industry]] called them one of the world's most "influential and pioneering acts", while the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] added ''A Rush of Blood to the Head'' to the [[List of 200 Definitive Albums in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame|200 Definitive Albums]] list and "Yellow" to the ''Songs That Shaped Rock and Roll'' exhibit. In 2023, the group featured on the first [[Time 100#Time 100 Climate|''Time'' 100 Climate]] ranking. Despite their popularity, they are considered [[Cultural impact of Coldplay#Public image|polarising cultural icons]].
